Graphical abstract A corrugated plate-like electrocatalyst is fabricated by a PVDF-assisted pyrolysis strategy using 2D ZIF-67 as the precursor, which realizes efficient active sites and rapid mass transfer, thus delivering appreciable performance towards ORR and OER in ZABs. Though Zn-air batteries (ZABs) are one of the most promising system for energy storage and conversion, challenge still persists in its commercial application due to the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER). Hereby, a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)-assisted pyrolysis strategy is proposed to develop a novel corrugated plate-like bifunctional electrocatalyst using two-dimensional zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (2D ZIF-67) as the precursor. The employed PVDF plays an important role in inheriting the original 2D structure of ZIF-67 and modulating the composition of the final products. As a result, a corrugated plate-like electrocatalyst, high-density Co nanoparticles decorated 2D Co, N, and F tri-doped carbon nanosheets, can be obtained. The acquired electrocatalyst enables efficient active sites and rapid mass transfer simultaneously, thus showing appreciable electrocatalytic performance for rechargeable Zn-air batteries. Undoubtedly, our proposed strategy offers a new perspective to the design of advanced oxygen electrocatalysts. Keywords Active sites Mass transfer Corrugated plate Oxygen electrocatalyst Zn-air batteries 1 Introduction The pursuit for safer, cheaper and higher efficient Zn-air batteries (ZABs) have spawned extensive interests in the field of energy storage and conversion [1–3]. Generally, ZABs store and produce electricity by redox reactions between Zn anode and oxygen cathode. However, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), as two fundamental reactions happening at the interface of oxygen cathode usually suffer from sluggish kinetics, remarkably affecting the electrochemical performance of ZABs [4–9]. As a matter of fact, the use of cost-effective bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts to accelerate the reaction kinetics is urgently required. To date, atomically dispersed transition metal and nitrogen co-doped carbon material (M-N-C), especially for Co-N-C, displays superior ORR performance [10–14]. And it is demonstrated that the existing Co-N x sites in Co-N-C are ideal catalytic sites for ORR due to their suitable binding energy towards oxygen intermediates, while the OER performance of these Co-N x sites generally prove much inferior to that of metallic Co nanoparticles [15]. In addition, it is accepted that there is a synergistic effect between Co-N x sites and the neighboring Co nanoparticles, which is in favor of further enhancing the ORR activity of Co-N-C electrocatalysts [16,17]. From this point of view, the construction of Co/Co-N-C system can be deemed as promising bifunctional active sites for both ORR and OER [18–20]. Apart from the construction of bifunctional active sites for ORR and OER, another prerequisite for realizing excellent catalytic performance is rapid mass transfer behavior. It is widely acknowledged that mass transfer is greatly affected by the morphology architecture of catalysts [21–24]. Two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets, similar to “flat plate” are demonstrated to be a favorable nanoreactor for rapid mass transfer. On one hand, the 2D structure with highly opened structure facilitate the accessibility of active sites and infiltration of electrolyte [25–28]. Moreover, this special architecture is usually featured with large specific surface area (SSA), which benefits uniform dispersion and full exposure of active sites [29–31]. In light of the above consideration, the design of 2D Co/Co-N-C system catches the possibility to show outstanding bifunctional catalytic performance for ORR and OER. Metal-organic framework (MOF) with tunable spatial morphology and chemical composition are widely viewed as common synthetic precursors [32–37]. Recently, nanosheet-like 2D ZIF-67 has come to light, and been regarded as a potential precursor to prepare 2D Co/Co-N-C system as it can incorporate the merits of ZIF-67 and 2D materials [38]. However, high metal loading of 2D ZIF-67 make it hard to be carbonized, otherwise it will confront serious aggregation and complete structure collapse during the pyrolysis, which will greatly limit its application [39]. Therefore, how to inherit or even optimize the structural advantage of 2D ZIF-67 during pyrolysis is challenging but significant. In addition, how to make the best use of rich Co species in 2D ZIF-67 and obtain highly active sites is another issue of critical concern. In this work, a facile polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)-assisted pyrolysis method was put forward to prepare 2D Co, N, and F tri-doped carbon nanosheets (CoNFC-NS) decorated with high-density Co nanoparticles (Co/CoNFC-NS-700, 700 represents pyrolysis temperature) by using 2D ZIF-67 as initial precursor. By systematical characterization and analysis, it is found that the introduced PVDF as heat-proof material not only provides F doping source, but also plays a vital role on inheriting the original structure of 2D ZIF-67 and modulating the composition of the final products. In addition to this, it is evidenced that the pyrolysis temperature has a great influence on the synthesis of Co/CoNFC-NS systems. When the pyrolysis temperature increased to 700 °C, Co nanoparticles begin to establish and anchor onto the 2D CoNFC-NS, which results in the formation of corrugated plate-like 2D Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Notably, the co-existing high-density Co nanoparticles and uniformly dispersed Co-N4 sites act as highly active bifunctional catalytic sites for ORR and OER. Additionally, high-density Co nanoparticles anchored onto the 2D CoNFC-NS function as corrugated plate nanoreactors, significantly boosting mass transfer. Benefitting from all these merits, the novel corrugated plate-like Co/CoNFC-NS-700 delivers excellent bifunctional catalytic performance in Zn-air batteries. Clearly, our proposed strategy provides a new perspective to the design of advanced electrocatalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of 2D ZIF-67 Co(NO3)2·6H2O and dimethylimidazole with a mass ratio of 1:1 were distributed into 30 mL of methanol under magnetic stirring. Then the obtained solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 2 h. Finally, the reaction product was washed by methanol for several times and dried at 60 °C overnight to get the 2D ZIF-67 precursor. For comparison, we also prepared ZIF-67 polyhedron by similar procedure expect for altering the mass ratio of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and dimethylimidazole to 1:2. More details about the synthesis of ZIF-67 polyhedron and 2D ZIF-67 can be found in Figs. S1 and S2. 2.2 Synthesis of Co/CoNFC-NS 2D ZIF-67 and PVDF power with a mass ratio of 1:1 were uniformly dispersed into N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) under ultrasonication and then dried at 60 °C overnight. Subsequently, the solid mixture was transferred to a tubular furnace and heated under N2 atmosphere at different temperatures (T = 400, 500, 600, 700, and 800 °C) for 2 h, and the final black products were denoted as Co/CoNFC-NS-T. 2.3 Synthesis of Co/CoNC 2D ZIF-67 was directly pyrolyzed under N2 atmosphere at different temperatures (T = 400, 500, 600, 700, and 800 °C) for 2 h, and the resultant products were named as Co/CoNC-T. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of Co/CoNFC-NS-700 As vividly presented in Figs. S1–S2, original ZIF-67 can be converted to specific 2D ZIF-67 due to the epitaxial growth during the hydrothermal process, and the obtained 2D ZIF-67 shows flower-like 2D nanosheets (Fig. 1 a). Then, the 2D ZIF-67 assisted by PVDF was pyrolyzed to produce 2D Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Firstly, scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) techniques were employed to detect the micromorphology. As seen in Fig. 1(b and c), Co/CoNFC-NS-700 well inherits the micromorphology of 2D ZIF-67 and consists of typical 2D carbon nanosheets and abundant Co nanoparticles. The average thickness of these nanosheets was analyzed by atomic force microscopy (AFM) and turns out to be ∼3 nm (Fig. S3). The TEM image in Fig. 1(d) also confirms enriched nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed onto 2D carbon nanosheets, and these nanoparticles with average size of ∼37 nm (Fig. S4) can be assigned to metallic Co, as verified by the (111) lattice plane shown in the HRTEM image (Fig. 1e) [40,41]. Fig. 1(f) shows the aberration-corrected high-angle-annular-dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) image. It is seen that individual bright spots are dispersed on the carbon nanosheets, corresponding to the isolated single Co atoms. Notably, Co element exists in two states, metallic Co nanoparticles and Co single atoms in carbon nanosheets. The elemental mapping images in Fig. 1(g) reflect the uniform distribution of Co, N, and F on the carbon matrix, implying successful incorporation of Co, N, and F atoms in Co/CoNFC-NS-700. It is evident that the doped F atoms mostly come from the introduced PVDF [42]. To further explore the local structure of Co atoms in carbon nanosheets, X-ray adsorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis was performed on the acid-leached Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Fig. 1(h) shows the Co k-edge XANES spectra. It can be seen that the absorption edge position of acid-leached Co/CoNFC-NS-700 was located between Co foil and Co3O4 samples, and approached to that of CoO sample, indicating that the chemical state of Co species in acid-leached Co/CoNFC-NS-700 predominately exists in the form of Co2+ [43]. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra in Fig. 1(i) reveal the radial distribution functions [44,45]. It can be seen that a prominent peak at 2.2 Å from the Co foil corresponds to the Co–Co bond. As for our target sample, only one prominent peak at 1.4 Å can be observed, which is associated with the scattering path of Co–N in reference to that of CoPc. It is well-demonstrated that the Co species exist as isolated single atoms by the N coordination [46]. To further confirm the atomic dispersion of Co species, the wavelet transfer (WT) contour plot is illustrated in Fig. S5, which can discriminate the backscattering atoms and offer the powerful resolution in both R and k spaces [47]. For the acid-leached Co/CoNFC-NS-700 sample, the intensity maximum near 3.8 Å−1 closely matches that of CoPc, suggesting the contribution from the backscattering between the Co and N atoms. No intensity maximum corresponding to the Co–Co was observed, indicating the state of single atom. The least-squares fitting curves in R and k space are performed, as depicted in Fig. 1(j) and Fig. S6. It can be concluded that Co atom coordinates with four N atoms with a scattering distance of 1.90 Å. More fitting parameters were listed in Table S1. All the results confirm the presence of atomic dispersed Co–N4 species in acid-leached Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Based on the above characterization results (e.g. XAFS, HRTEM, AC HAADF-STEM and so on), it can be revealed that Co nanoparticles and atomically Co-N4 moieties co-exist in the Co/CoNFC-NS-700 sample. 3.2 The role of PVDF for the formation of Co/CoNFC-NS In order to explore the intuitive influence of PVDF on the formation of Co/CoNFC-NS systems, SEM images of Co/CoNFC-NS-T at different temperature were presented in Fig. 2 (a). It was observed that intact 2D structure with no clear nanoparticles can be discerned on the nanosheets of Co/CoNFC-NS-T (T = 400, 500, and 600 °C). Dense Co nanoparticles begin to precipitate on the carbon nanosheets when the pyrolysis temperature increases to 700 °C, leading to the corrugated plate-like structure. While, large Co blocks exist in Co/CoNFC-NS-800. This result may be ascribed to the fact that overhigh (over 700 °C) pyrolysis temperature can lead to serious agglomeration of Co nanoparticles, which is likely to destroy the 2D carbon nanosheets. By contrast, the preparation of Co/CoNC-T was also accomplished under the condition of without adding PVDF, and the corresponding schematic diagram of preparation was exhibited in Fig. 2(b). Notably, the morphology of Co/CoNC-T (Fig. 2c) is quite different from that of Co/CoNFC-NS-T at the same temperature. To be specific, it was found that Co/CoNC-400 maintains nanosheet shape, but this morphology will be damaged when the pyrolysis temperature exceeds 400 °C. By comparison, it can be deduced that the existence of PVDF strengthens the thermal stability, which keeps the 2D nanosheets from 400 °C for Co/CoNC to 700 °C for Co/CoNFC-NS. This phenomenon indicates that the existence of PVDF plays a role of inheriting the original structure of 2D ZIF-67 and prohibiting its structure collapse during high-temperature pyrolysis. The result is also supported by TGA curve. It can be seen in Fig. S7 that 2D ZIF-67 undergoes the sharp weight loss at 210 °C corresponding to the decomposition of the contained hydroxide composition [48]. Comparatively, under the assistance of PVDF, the weight loss will not happen until it reaches higher temperature (280 °C) and the process become piecewise and gentle. The result indicates that thermal stability of 2D ZIF-67 can be improved after introducing the PVDF, thus ensuring Co/CoNFC-NS-T inherent the original structure of 2D ZIF-67 under the higher pyrolysis temperature. Apart from the morphology change, the structure of the obtained Co/CoNFC-NS-T and Co/CoNC-T samples was also measured by ex-situ XRD techniques. It can be seen from Fig. 2(d) that the Co species in 2D ZIF-67 will be transformed to CoO under relatively low pyrolysis temperature, and reduced to metallic Co when the temperature reaches 700 °C or even higher. In the absence of PVDF (Fig. 2e), Co species are firstly converted to Co3O4 and CoO at first, and then will turn out to be metallic Co under the lower pyrolytic temperature, suggesting that the presence of PVDF is able to mitigate the reduction of Co species during the heating process to some extents. It is clear that the introduction of PVDF also have important impact on the composition of the final product. 3.3 The effect of temperature on the formation of Co/CoNFC-NS On the above analysis, it is clear that pyrolysis temperature plays the vital role on the structure and composition of the pyrolytic products. Herein, the Raman, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) are also employed to further uncover this effect by probing difference of Co/CoNFC-NS-T. As depicted in Fig. 3 (a), all the Raman spectra exhibit two typical peaks of D band (∼1350 cm−1) and G band (∼1580 cm−1) [49,50]. It was observed that the intensity ratio of these two peaks (I D/I G) decreases from 0.85 for Co/CoNFC-NS-400 to 0.72 for Co/CoNFC-NS-800, indicating enhanced graphitization degree caused by high-temperature pyrolysis [51]. The BET technology was used to analyze the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the surface property of Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples. Clearly, all isothermal curves in Fig. 3(b) belong to type-Ⅳ isotherms featured with capillary condensation phenomenon, indicating typical mesoporous property. The specific surface area (SSA) of Co/CoNFC-NS-600 (315.0 m2 g−1) and Co/CoNFC-NS-700 (338.6 m2 g−1) is proven to be much larger than that of Co/CoNFC-NS-800 (118.3 m2 g−1), which is mostly caused by structure collapse of Co/CoNFC-NS-800. The pore size distribution curves in Fig. 3(c) indicate the formation of hierarchical micro/mesoporous structure in the resultant Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples. The as-formed micro/mesoporous structure not only facilitates the infiltration of electrolyte and transport of ions, but also benefits the exposure of catalytic sites [52,53]. For better comparison, the SSA of Co/CoNC-700 (only 4.8 m2 g−1) is also tested, and proven to be much smaller than those of Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples, implying that the introduction of PVDF can restrict the agglomeration of Co/CoNFC-NS and greatly enlarge the SSA. XPS technique was utilized to further examine the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the chemical composition of Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples. As shown in Fig. 3(d), two distinct peaks at ∼793.6 and ∼778.2 eV in the high-resolution Co 2p spectra can be indexed to the Co 2p 1/2 and Co 2p 3/2 peaks. The Co 2p 3/2 peak can be further deconvoluted to two configurations, Co0 in the form of Co–Co (∼780.8 eV) and Co2+ in the form of Co–O/Co–N bond (∼782.7 eV) [54–56]. The ratio of Co0 to Co2+ can be figured out to be 1.21 for Co/CoNFC-NS-700 and 1.27 for Co/CoNFC-NS-800, respectively. The increased Co0/Co2+ value reflects increased amounts of metallic Co nanoparticles in Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples, indicating that higher pyrolysis temperature is in favor of the establishment of more metallic Co. Metal Co nanoparticles have been proved to greatly improve the OER catalytic activity. The high-resolution N 1s spectra in Fig. 3(e) contain four various configurations, pyridinic-N (∼397.5 eV), Co–N (∼399.5 eV), pyrrolic-N (∼400.1 eV), and graphitic-N (∼401.5 eV). The emergence of Co–N bond in Co 2p spectra and Co–N configuration in N 1s spectra confirm the formation of Co-N-C in Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples, which is one of most efficient active sites for ORR. In addition to this, it is observed that the relative content of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N decreases, while the relative content of graphitic-N increases with the growing the pyrolysis temperature, indicating that higher pyrolysis temperature is beneficial to the transformation of graphitic-N [57,58]. More graphitic-N could boost electron transfer ability and provide more active sites [59]. As for the F 1s spectrum (Fig. 3f), the peak at ∼686.6 eV can be attributed to C–F semi-ionic bond, suggesting successfully F doping through introducing PVDF [60]. It was confirmed that F doping plays an important role in improving the performance of carbon-based catalysts. On one hand, F atom possesses the highest electronegativity as compared to other atoms, so F doping can effectively break the electroneutrality of the carbon framework, thus ameliorating its charge transfer behavior [61]. In addition, it was substantiated that F doping can enhance the O2 adsorption energy and elongate the O = O bond distance, which brings about much improved oxygen catalytic activity [62]. On the basis of the aforementioned characterization and analysis, it is evidenced that the introduction of PVDF not only provides F doping source, but also plays a role in strengthening the thermal stability and inheriting the original 2D structure of 2D ZIF-67. Additionally, it is apparent that pyrolysis temperature also has a great effect on the synthesis of Co/CoNFC-NS. When the pyrolysis temperature is no more than 700 °C, all the Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples can perfectly inherit original structure of 2D ZIF-67 and keep the 2D nanosheets architecture. While, there is a little difference in Co/CoNFC-NS-700. High-density Co nanoparticles come into being and anchor onto the 2D CoNFC-NS. The co-existing high-density Co nanoparticles and uniformly dispersed Co–N4 sites as highly active catalytic sites are expected to deliver excellent catalytic performance for ORR and OER. 3.4 Analysis of mass transfer behavior In addition to the construction of highly active Co/Co-N-C system, the mass transfer behavior should be considered as another key factor for achieving excellent catalytic performance [63–65]. Based on previous reports, the mass transfer behavior is usually estimated by the ion/molecule diffusion coefficient (D) and the D value can be figured out by Randle-Sevcik equation (more details can be seen in Supporting Information) [58,66]. Fig. 4 (a–c) shows the cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves at different scan rates, and the corresponding I p vs. v 1/2 curves are presented in Fig. 4(d). The perfectible linearity manifested that the electrochemical behavior is mainly ascribed to ionic diffusion-controlled behavior. Furthermore, the largest slope for Co/CoNFC-NS-700 indicates the fastest ion/molecule diffusion rate [67]. Also, the ion diffusion can be reflected by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) plots. The Nyquist plots and corresponding equivalent circuit model was given in Fig. 4(e) and Fig. S8. It is seen that all plots exhibit a depressed semicircle in high-frequency region and a straight line in low-frequency region. The diameter of the depressed semicircle is related to the charge transfer resistance (R ct), and the slope of the straight line is correlated with the mass transfer behavior in the tripe-phase boundary. Generally, the D value can be evaluated by the slope of the straight line, and the specified calculation can be found in Supporting Information [20]. It was observed in Fig. 4(f) that the Co/CoNFC-NS-700 possesses the minimum slope value, suggesting the highest D value, i.e. the most rapid diffusion behavior. Evidently, different Co/CoNFC-NS-T samples display different mass transfer behaviors. The mass transfer capability of Co/CoNFC-NS-800 is much inferior to the other samples, which is mostly due to structure collapse during high-temperature pyrolysis. With regard to the Co/CoNFC-NS-700, high-density Co nanoparticles anchored onto the 2D CoNFC-NS much resembles the “corrugated plate” of heat-exchange reactors [68], while the Co/CoNFC-NS-600 without interfacial Co nanoparticles is just like common “flat plate”. To further analyze the influence of structural difference on mass transfer, finite element analysis (FEA) simulations were conducted by using CMOSOL Multiphysics [69]. Given the distinct structural characteristics of as-prepared sample, the primary difference lies in the nanoparticles within/upon the nanosheets. In this regard, the corresponding “corrugated plate” and “flat plate” models were established and placed in the center of the calculated domain. Specifically, water was introduced from the left boundary and outflowed from the right, along with an inflow velocity of 2.0 m/s at the entrance, which simulates the electrolyte flow induced by the rotation of electrodes. Herein, different colors represent various velocities of simulated flow fields, which are identified as an important index to evaluate the mass diffusion behavior [70]. The simulation results in Fig. 4(g) show that the flow velocity is significantly influenced by the geometric architectures, and the main flow rate in the “corrugated plate” is proven to be faster and more uneven than that in the “flat plate”. It can be calculated that the average flow rate of “corrugated plate” nanoreactor is 2.82 m s−1, surpassing that of flat plate (2.00 m s−1). The fast velocity in “corrugated plate” indicates superior mass transfer capability of Co/CoNFC-NS-700, which ensures efficient electrolyte diffusion and facilitates the catalytic process. 3.5 Electrochemical performance Firstly, the ORR performance was analyzed by CV measurement in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), all CV curves tested in N2-saturated electrolyte exhibits typical rectangle-like shape. When O2 was bubbled into the electrolyte, an obvious oxygen reduction peak appears. It was observed that the Co/CoNFC-NS-700 electrode possesses the most positive peak, which signifies the best catalytic activity toward ORR. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test was conducted to further assess the ORR performance. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the Co/CoNFC-NS-700 electrode delivers the most positive half-wave potential (E 1/2 = 0.82 V) and the largest limiting current density (J L = 5.68 mA cm−2), which is comparable to the benchmark Pt/C catalyst (E 1/2 = 0.82 V, J L = 5.46 mA cm−2). Fig. S9 exhibits the kinetic current density (J k) of different catalysts at 0.8 V. Clearly, the larger J k value of Co/CoNFC-NS-700 electrode demonstrates the faster ORR kinetics. Besides, electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) was tested to assess the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA). As depicted in Fig. S10, The C dl of Co/CoNFC-NS-700 is much larger than that of other counterparts, indicating more available active sites can be exposed in Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Fig. 5(c) shows the LSV curves of Co/CoNFC-NS-700 at different rotation speeds. The corresponding Koutechy-Levich (K-L) plot (inset of Fig. 5c) displays good linearity and the electron transfer number (n) was figured out to be nearly four, suggesting ideal four-electron oxygen reduction pathway. SCN– poison experiment was also conducted in Fig. S11. After introducing SCN–, an obvious negative shift of half-potential and significantly decrease of current density appears in the LSV curves. The inferior catalytic performance might be due to the fact that the SCN– blocks the active sites of Co–N4 moieties. Clearly, it can be determined that Co–N4 species in Co/CoNFC-NS-700 play a important role in ORR catalysis. As depicted in Fig. S12(a), negligible degradation can be observed after long-term cycles, suggesting Co/CoNFC-NS-700 electrode delivers desirable long-term durability. The SEM image of Co/CoNFC-NS-700 after cycling is given in Fig. S13. Co/CoNFC-NS-700 still remains the original morphology, in which Co nanoparticles are well decorated onto the carbon nanosheets without any agglomeration, again confirming the desirable structural stability of Co/CoNFC-NS-700. Chronoamperometric technique was used to test the methanol tolerance in Fig. S12(b). Compared with the Pt/C, Co/CoNFC-NS-700 displays the relatively more stable current response, demonstrating the favorable tolerance to the methanol crossover. To corroborate the bifunctional catalytic activity of these samples, the OER performance was also measured by a standard three-electrode system in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. The LSV curves on different electrodes are shown in Fig. 5(d). The overpotential ( η ) at 10 mA cm−2 on Co/CoNFC-NS-700 ( η = 345 mV) is much smaller than that on Co/CoNFC-NS-600 ( η = 558 mV) and Co/CoNFC-NS-800 ( η = 449 mV), and is much close to that of commercial RuO2 catalyst. As seen from Fig. 5(e), the Tafel slope on Co/CoNFC-NS-700 (114 mV/dec) is much smaller than that of Co/CoNFC-NS-600 (191 mV/dec) and Co/CoNFC-NS-800 (177 mV/dec), showing much faster OER kinetics. Fig. 5(f) shows ORR and OER bifunctional electrocatalytic performance of different samples. The performance is usually evaluated by the potential difference (ΔE) between the half-wave potential (E 1/2) of ORR and the OER potential at 10 mA cm−2 (E j=10) [71]. The Co/CoNFC-NS-700 displays the relatively small ΔE value of 0.75 V, much lower than that of Pt/C and RuO2, implying its favorable bifunctional activity toward ORR and OER. The desirable performance might be ascribed to the synergistic effect of Co nanoparticles and Co–N x sites. The small ΔE can be comparable to that of other various transitional metal-based catalysts, as listed in Table S2. The small ΔE value endows the synthesized Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalyst with potential to be a prospective cathode in Zn-air batteries (ZABs) [72]. In order to verify its possible practice, liquid-state ZABs was assembled by using Co/CoNFC-NS-700 as the cathode catalyst (Fig. 6 a). As depicted in Fig. 6(b), the open-circuit voltage is 1.42 V, surpassing that of commercial Pt/C. Fig. 6(c) presents the polarization curves and the corresponding power density. ZABs based on Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalysts show the high peak power density of 129.0 mW cm−2 at the current density of 189.1 mA cm−2, exceeding that of Pt/C (104.0 mW cm−2 at current density of 159.3 mA cm−2) under the same condition. The favorable performance is might due to excellent conductivity and optimized mass transport benefit from the novel corrugated plate-like structure [73]. The high powder density is proven to be enough to power a light board and a small fan ( Fig. 6d). As shown in Fig. 6(e) the ZABs based on Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalyst delivers better rate performance than that equipped with Pt/C catalyst. To verify the excellent bifunctional catalytic performance, we also constructed rechargeable ZAB with Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalyst. Strikingly, ZABs based on Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalyst shows little polarization, good chargeability and stable voltage platform after 300 charge/discharge cycles (Fig. 6f), well demonstrating the robust durability. To better analyze the dynamic change in the batteries, the EIS plots of Co/CoNFC-NS-700-based ZABs were performed and fitted based on the equivalent circuit model (Fig. S14). The corresponding fitting results were listed in Table S3. It was found that the solution resistance (R s) values under different potentials are similar, while the charge transfer resistance (R ct) value under different potentials varies with the applied potentials. The R ct value at open circuit potential (OCP) is 81.5 Ω, decreasing to 12.6 Ω at 1.2 V and only 5.9 Ω at 0.8 V during discharging process, indicating accelerated reaction kinetics [74]. Notably, the post-charge values of R ct were only marginally larger than those observed after discharging. The small increase in value and the preservation of original shape of Nyquist plot confirm the electrochemical durability and reversibility of ZABs [75]. Flexible solid-state ZABs was also assembled using Ni foam as current collector (Fig. 6g). As shown in Fig. 6(h), Co/CoNFC-NS-700 catalyst based ZABs delivers high open-circuit voltage of 1.34 V and it can also show high voltage of 1.33 V when bended at 120°. According to Fig. 6(i), Co/CoNFC-NS-700 based ZABs possesses peak power density of 97.1 mW cm−2, which is much higher than that of Pt/C (56.2 mW cm−2). In fact, one ZAB can be enough to light up a light board with “Zn-air” symbol and power a small fun (Fig. 6j) Furthermore, there is only small voltage drop in Fig. 6(k) when the current density is increased from 1 to 10 mA cm−2, indicating the excellent rate performance. Fig. 6(l) exhibits the galvanostatic cycling stability tests of ZABs. Notably, the ZABs fabricated with Co/CoNFC-NS-700 outputs relatively stable charging voltage of 1.09 V and discharge voltage of 1.98 V after cycling over 100 cycles, again confirming its potential practical value. 4 Conclusions In summary, Co nanoparticles anchored onto 2D Co, N, and F tri-doped carbon nanosheets (Co/CoNFC-NS) system can be successfully fabricated by a PVDF-assisted pyrolysis strategy using 2D ZIF-67 as the initial precursor. The result confirms that the employed PVDF not only provides F doping source, but also plays a key role in inheriting the 2D structure of ZIF-67 and regulating the composition of the final products. In addition to this, it is proven that the pyrolysis temperature has a great impact on the synthesis of Co/CoNFC-NS system. When the pyrolysis temperature is set as 700 °C, high-density Co nanoparticles come into being and establish on the 2D CoNFC-NS, which resembles a corrugated plate nanoreactor. On one hand, the co-existence of high-density Co nanoparticles and abundant Co–N4 sites in Co/CoNFC-NS-700 act as highly active bifunctional catalytic sites. Furthermore, the unique corrugated plate structure assembled by 2D CoNFC-NS and Co nanoparticles gives rise to rapid mass transfer. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of efficient active sites and rapid mass transfer, the resultant Co/CoNFC-NS-700 delivers favorable electrocatalytic performance towards both ORR and OER. When employed as the cathode catalyst in Zn-air batteries, the Co/CoNFC-NS-700 also presents excellent electrochemical performance. Clearly, our proposed strategy offers a new perspective to the design of advanced oxygen electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Though Zn-air batteries (ZABs) are one of the most promising system for energy storage and conversion, challenge still persists in its commercial application due to the sluggish kinetics of oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER). Hereby, a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)-assisted pyrolysis strategy is proposed to develop a novel corrugated plate-like bifunctional electrocatalyst using two-dimensional zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (2D ZIF-67) as the precursor. The employed PVDF plays an important role in inheriting the original 2D structure of ZIF-67 and modulating the composition of the final products. As a result, a corrugated plate-like electrocatalyst, high-density Co nanoparticles decorated 2D Co, N, and F tri-doped carbon nanosheets, can be obtained. The acquired electrocatalyst enables efficient active sites and rapid mass transfer simultaneously, thus showing appreciable electrocatalytic performance for rechargeable Zn-air batteries. Undoubtedly, our proposed strategy offers a new perspective to the design of advanced oxygen electrocatalysts.
